review.title: Logical Inference Algorithms and Matrix Representations for Probabilistic Conditional Independence
review.abstract: Logical inference algorithms for conditional independence (CI) statements have important applications from testing consistency during knowledge elicitation to constraintbased structure learning of graphical models. We prove that the implication problem for CI statements is decidable, given that the size of the domains of the random variables is known and fixed. We will present an approximate logical inference algorithm which combines a falsification and a novel validation algorithm. The validation algorithm represents each set of CI statements as a sparse 0-1 matrix A and validates instances of the implication problem by solving specific linear programs with constraint matrix A. We will show experimentally that the algorithm is both effective and efficient in validating and falsifying instances of the probabilistic CI implication problem.

sections.text: We demonstrate that the implication problem for cochlear implant statements can be decided because the size of the domains of the random variables is known and fixed. We present an approximate logical inference algorithm that combines falsification and a new validation algorithm. The validation algorithm presents each set of cochlear implant statements as a sparse 0-1 matrix A and validates instances of the implication problem by solving specific linear programs with the constraint matrix A. We will demonstrate experimentally that the algorithm is both effective and efficient in validating and falsifying instances of the probable cochlear implant problem.

sections.text: We will take advantage of one of the recently discovered falsification algorithms and introduce a new validation algorithm that encodes instances of the implication problem as linear programs with sparse 0-1 constraint matrices. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Logical inference algorithms for probabilistic conditional independence statements have several important applications, ranging from verifying consistency during knowledge generation to restriction-based structural learning of graphical models (Gandhi et al. [7]). We proved that the implication problem is decisive for cochlear implant statements because the size of the domains of the random variables is known and fixed. Subsequently, we presented an approximate inference algorithm that combines a falsification and a novel validation algorithm. We experimentally demonstrated that the approximate inference algorithm represents each set of cochlear implant statements as a minimal sparse 0-1 matrix A and validates instances of the implication problem by solving linear programs with A as a constraint matrix. We demonstrated that the approximate inference algorithm is both effective and efficient at validating and falsifying instances of the implication problem as well as we hope that the implication algorithm will prove useful for both researchers.
